text: From a fresh growler that was filled (counter pressure) 48 hours ago. The aroma on this is really nice with light hints of peat, an underlying sweetness, and a little nuttiness. Light berries are also present. Very nice aroma. An attractive transparent amber body is present on this with a smallish off-white head. Starts with a nice and sweet maltiness. This is a nice malt bomb with delicate peat flavors coming through the middle. Nice carbonation. Virtually no bitterness. Extremely easy-drinking and very sessionable. This is just a world-class example of the style.

Pours a thin head on a clear amber colored body.
Aroma is watery caramel.
Taste is caramel, mild lemon bitterness, more caramel.
Texture is thin.
slightly above average irish red. not a style I get excited about, but this was done well. carmel and toffee on the nose. flavor has light citrus hops and nuts as well.
Tap at West Coast Invitational 2015. Pours ruddy with a slight off-white head. Aroma is mildly malty. Flavor is malty. Barest hints of hop. Irish reds are not my thing.

Bottle. Pours clear reddish amber with a medium creamy beige head with good staying power and nice lacing. Aroma is caramel, nutty, some grass. Flavor is medium sweet and quite light bitter, malty, nutty, with just a touch of grassy hop. Medium body, Very solid for style.
Deep reddish amber with an slightly off white head. Light nutty smells. Creamy nut taste with a slight hop bitter that balances by the end of the sip. palate left coated with nutty bitter.
On tap at Capitol Beer& Tap Room. Pours reddish brown with a thick tan head and a light smoked malt aroma. There is a medium-bodied smoked malt flavor with a dry finish.
Draft at the brewery. Reddish pour, with off-white head. Sweet caramel malt, a bit musty, light hops, and more caramel malt. A more authentic Irish ale
Classic Red, malty with some fruit, and mediumly hopped towards the finish. Very sessionable!
Draft at the brewery.  Reddish pour, with off-white head.  Sweet caramel malt, a bit musty, light hops, and more caramel malt.  As with most irish ales, I dont like it much.

Excellent red.  Aroma is sweet malts, and a little of that classic scotch ale peat... I guess thats why theyre referring to it as a Celtic Ale.  Sweet malt, and a little peat smoked malt up front, and a long, complex, and very large finish with just a hint of bitterness.  This is a very big beer considering the ABV.  I like it a lot.
